meta.dc:rights: The Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region

main.longTitle: An Ordinance to amend and consolidate the law relating to the courts’ jurisdiction, powers, practice and procedure in family matters; to establish the Family Procedure Rules Committee for making a consolidated set of family procedure rules; and to make related amendments.

part.name: P1
part.heading: Preliminary

section.name: s1
section.heading: Short title and commencement

subsection.content: This Ordinance may be cited as the Family Procedure Ordinance.
Subject to subsection (3), this Ordinance comes into operation on a day to be appointed by the Chief Justice by notice published in the Gazette.

subsection.leadIn: The following provisions come into operation on the day on which this Ordinance is published in the Gazette—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: sections 1, 2, 3(1) (except paragraph (e)), (2) and (4) and 15;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Part 4;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: section 28 (in so far as it relates to section 76 of the Schedule);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: section 76 of the Schedule.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Interpretation

subsection.leadIn: In this Ordinance—
subsection.def: CFI means the Court of First Instance;

def.name: CFIJudge
def.leadIn: CFI Judge (原訟法庭法官) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Chief Judge;

paragraph.name: b
c

subsection.def: child (未成年人) means a person under 18 years of age;
court (法庭) means the CFI or the Family Court;
Family Court (家事法庭) means a division of the District Court assigned by the Chief Justice to deal with family proceedings;
Family Judge (家事法官) means a judge, as defined by section 2 of the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336), who sits in the Family Court;
family proceeding (家事法律程序)—see section 3;
financial order (財務命令)—see section 4;

def.name: HighCourtJudge
def.leadIn: High Court Judge (高等法院法官) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a CFI Judge; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a Justice of Appeal of the Court of Appeal;

subsection.def: inherent jurisdiction (固有司法管轄權) means the CFI’s power to make an order, or determine an issue, in respect of a child (including in a wardship proceeding) to ensure that the child is protected and properly taken care of, where it would be just and equitable to do so unless restricted by an enactment or case law;
inherent jurisdiction proceeding (固有司法管轄權法律程序) means a proceeding started in the CFI under its inherent jurisdiction;
judge (法官) means a CFI Judge or a Family Judge;

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to a family proceeding in the High Court, means a Master of the High Court; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to a family proceeding in the Family Court, means a Master of the District Court;

subsection.def: Master of the District Court (區域法院聆案官) means a Master within the meaning of sections 14, 14A and 14B of the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336);
Master of the High Court (高等法院聆案官) means a Master as defined by section 2 of the High Court Ordinance (Cap. 4);

def.name: MatrimonialCause
def.leadIn: matrimonial cause (婚姻訴訟) means a proceeding for any of the following matters—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: divorce;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: nullity of marriage;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: judicial separation;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: presumption of death and dissolution of marriage;

def.name: PracticeDirection
def.leadIn: Practice Direction (實務指示) means a direction made under section 22 by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Chief Justice; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a High Court Judge designated by the Chief Justice under section 22(2);

subsection.def: prescribed (訂明) means prescribed by the Rules;

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to a family proceeding in the High Court, means the Registrar of the High Court; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to a family proceeding in the Family Court, means the Registrar of the District Court;

subsection.def: Registrar of the District Court (區域法院司法常務官) means the Registrar as defined by section 2 of the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336);
Registrar of the High Court (高等法院司法常務官) means the Registrar as defined by section 2 of the High Court Ordinance (Cap. 4);
Rules (《規則》) means the rules made by the Rules Committee under Part 4;
Rules Committee (規則委員會) means the Family Procedure Rules Committee established by section 24.

subsection.leadIn: In this Ordinance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a reference to a proceeding being started has the same meaning as the proceeding being commenced or instituted even though the words “commenced”, “instituted” or similar expressions are used in relation to such a proceeding in another Ordinance; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a reference to a permission of a court to do an act has the same meaning as the leave of the court to do the act even though the word “leave” is used in relation to such an act in another Ordinance.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Meaning of family proceeding

subsection.leadIn: A family proceeding is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an inherent jurisdiction proceeding;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a matrimonial cause;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a proceeding other than a matrimonial cause started under the Matrimonial Causes Ordinance (Cap. 179);

subparagraph.content: an Ordinance specified in subsection (2); or
any subsidiary legislation made under the Ordinance; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: a proceeding started under any repealed legislation.

subsection.leadIn: For subsection (1)(d)(i), the following Ordinances are specified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Guardianship of Minors Ordinance (Cap. 13);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Separation and Maintenance Orders Ordinance (Cap. 16);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the Marriage Reform Ordinance (Cap. 178);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the Marriage Ordinance (Cap. 181);

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the Married Persons Status Ordinance (Cap. 182);

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the Legitimacy Ordinance (Cap. 184);

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the Maintenance Orders (Reciprocal Enforcement) Ordinance (Cap. 188);

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: the Domestic and Cohabitation Relationships Violence Ordinance (Cap. 189);
the Matrimonial Proceedings and Property Ordinance (Cap. 192);

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: the Adoption Ordinance (Cap. 290);

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: the Parent and Child Ordinance (Cap. 429);
the Inheritance (Provision for Family and Dependants) Ordinance (Cap. 481);

paragraph.name: m
paragraph.content: the Child Abduction and Custody Ordinance (Cap. 512);

paragraph.name: n
paragraph.content: the Mainland Judgments in Matrimonial and Family Cases (Reciprocal Recognition and Enforcement) Ordinance (Cap. 639).

subsection.leadIn: In subsection (1)(e)—
subsection.def: repealed legislation (被廢除法例) means any of the following subsidiary legislation repealed by the Schedule—(a)the Attachment of Income Order Rules (Cap. 13 sub. leg. A);(b)the Matrimonial Causes Rules (Cap. 179 sub. leg. A);(c)the Maintenance Orders (Reciprocal Enforcement) Rules (Cap. 188 sub. leg. A);(d)the Domestic and Cohabitation Relationships Violence Rules (Cap. 189 sub. leg. A);(e)the Adoption Rules (Cap. 290 sub. leg. A);(f)the Convention Adoption Rules (Cap. 290 sub. leg. D);(g)the Mainland Judgments in Matrimonial and Family Cases (Reciprocal Recognition and Enforcement) Rules (Cap. 639 sub. leg. A).

subsection.content: To avoid doubt, a family proceeding includes any subsequent action or application brought to vary, discharge, suspend, rescind or set aside an order made by the court in a family proceeding or revive such an order, where no error of the court is alleged in relation to the making of the order.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Meaning of financial order

subsection.leadIn: A financial order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is an order made under a provision specified in subsection (2); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: includes an order that varies, discharges, suspends, rescinds or sets aside such an order, or revives such an order that has been suspended.

subsection.leadIn: For subsection (1)(a), the following provisions are specified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: section 10(2), 11(1)(b), 12(b) or 13(2), (3) or (4) of the Guardianship of Minors Ordinance (Cap. 13);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: section 5(1)(c), (d) or (e), 7 or 9 of the Separation and Maintenance Orders Ordinance (Cap. 16);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: section 17A of the Matrimonial Causes Ordinance (Cap. 179);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: section 6 of the Married Persons Status Ordinance (Cap. 182);

paragraph.name: e
f
paragraph.content: section 3, 4, 5, 6, 6A, 8, 11, 13, 15, 16, 17 or 23 or Part IIA of the Matrimonial Proceedings and Property Ordinance (Cap. 192) (except section 29AC of that Ordinance concerning the leave of the CFI or the Family Court being required for applications for financial relief);

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: section 4, 7, 8, 9 or 12 of the Inheritance (Provision for Family and Dependants) Ordinance (Cap. 481).

section.name: s5
section.heading: Application of this Ordinance

subsection.content: This Ordinance applies to every family proceeding, whether it is in the High Court or the Family Court.

To avoid doubt, unless otherwise provided by this Ordinance, this Ordinance applies to a family proceeding that was started in, or transferred or retransferred to, the High Court or the Family Court before the commencement date of this section.

part.name: P2
part.heading: Jurisdiction and Powers of Courts in Family Proceedings

section.name: s6
section.heading: Matters within CFI’s exclusive jurisdiction

subsection.leadIn: Subject to section 7(2), the CFI has exclusive jurisdiction over the family proceedings for the following matters—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an application for interim relief under section 21M of the High Court Ordinance (Cap. 4);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an application to obtain consent of the CFI to the marriage of a ward of court under section 14(2) of the Marriage Ordinance (Cap. 181);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an appeal against the decision of the Registrar (as defined by section 2 of the Marriage Ordinance (Cap. 181)) (Registrar of Marriages) on a person’s right to forbid a certificate of the Registrar of Marriages being issued under section 18 of that Ordinance;

paragraph.name: d
e
paragraph.content: an application under section 23B of the Adoption Ordinance (Cap. 290) by the Director of Social Welfare for an order passing care and control of an infant (as defined by section 2 of that Ordinance) with a view to the adoption of the infant by a person not residing in Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: an application under Part 2 of the Child Abduction and Custody Ordinance (Cap. 512).

subsection.content: Subject to section 7(2), the CFI also has exclusive jurisdiction over an application for an order that may be made under the CFI’s inherent jurisdiction, including an application to make a child a ward of court.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Matters within Family Court’s jurisdiction

subsection.content: Unless otherwise provided by an enactment, the Family Court has jurisdiction over all family proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: The Family Court has jurisdiction over a family proceeding (or an application in an inherent jurisdiction proceeding) that falls within the CFI’s exclusive jurisdiction if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a family proceeding—the proceeding is transferred by the CFI to the Family Court under section 8(3); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for an application—the application is transferred by the CFI to the Family Court under section 9(2).

subsection.content: The Family Court has jurisdiction over a family proceeding even if the amount claimed in the proceeding is more than the limit of the District Court’s jurisdiction under the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336).

The Family Court has jurisdiction to make an order concerning interest in or related to land in a family proceeding even if the annual rent or the rateable value of the land, ascertained under the Rating Ordinance (Cap. 116), is more than the limit of the District Court’s jurisdiction under the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336).

section.name: s8
section.heading: Transfer of proceedings between CFI and Family Court

subsection.content: This section applies in relation to every family proceeding (other than an inherent jurisdiction proceeding).

The Family Court may, on its own initiative or at the instigation of a party, transfer a family proceeding before it to the CFI either in whole or in part if, having regard to all the circumstances, the Family Court considers that the proceeding ought to be heard in the CFI.

subsection.leadIn: The CFI may, on its own initiative or at the instigation of a party, transfer or retransfer a family proceeding before it to the Family Court, either in whole or in part—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for the conduct of a financial dispute resolution hearing or a children dispute resolution hearing; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if, having regard to all the circumstances, the CFI considers that the proceeding ought to be heard in the Family Court.

subsection.leadIn: If a family proceeding has been transferred from the CFI to the Family Court, the Family Court may not retransfer the proceeding back to the CFI unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Family Court is satisfied that there is a change in circumstances since the transfer from the CFI such that, having regard to all the circumstances, the Family Court considers that the proceeding ought to be heard in the CFI; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Family Court is so directed by the CFI.

subsection.content: In considering whether a family proceeding should be transferred or retransferred from one court to another, the court must, if a child is involved, regard the best interests of the child as the paramount consideration.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Transfer of applications in CFI’s inherent jurisdiction proceedings

subsection.content: This section applies only in relation to an inherent jurisdiction proceeding.

subsection.leadIn: The CFI may, on its own initiative or at the instigation of a party, transfer an application in an inherent jurisdiction proceeding before it to the Family Court either in whole or in part if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the nature of the issues of fact or law involved makes the application more suitable for hearing in the Family Court; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the application falls within the Family Court’s jurisdiction.

subsection.content: The Family Court may, on its own initiative or at the instigation of a party, retransfer the application back to the CFI if the Family Court is satisfied that there is a change in circumstances since the transfer from the CFI such that, having regard to the nature of the issues of fact or law involved, the Family Court considers that the application ought to be heard in the CFI.

subsection.leadIn: However, the Family Court must retransfer the application back to the CFI if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a decision is required as to whether the child involved should remain a ward of court;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Family Court has no jurisdiction in dealing with the matter in issue; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the Family Court is so directed by the CFI.

subsection.content: In considering whether an application should be transferred or retransferred from one court to another, the court must, if a child is involved, regard the best interests of the child as the paramount consideration.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Determination of family proceedings started under other Ordinances
section.content: If the court exercises the jurisdiction under this Ordinance over a family proceeding started under another Ordinance, the court must make its determination in accordance with the provisions of that Ordinance and any subsidiary legislation made under that Ordinance.

section.name: s11
section.heading: Power to make declaration of beneficial ownership in favour of or against third party

subsection.content: In a family proceeding, the court has power to make a declaration of beneficial ownership in favour of or against a third party.

The court must, before making a declaration of beneficial ownership in favour of or against a third party, direct that the third party be joined as a party to the proceeding or that notice of the proceeding be served on the third party, unless it is not practicable to do so.

section.name: s12
section.heading: Finality of court order
section.content: Unless otherwise provided by an enactment, an order of the court in a family proceeding is final and conclusive between the parties.

section.name: s13
section.heading: Powers of judge

subsection.leadIn: If an enactment or a Practice Direction provides for the court to perform a function in relation to a family proceeding, then unless otherwise provided by another enactment, the function may be performed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to a proceeding in the CFI—by a CFI Judge; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to a proceeding in the Family Court—by a Family Judge.

subsection.content: A CFI Judge hearing a family proceeding has all the powers conferred on a judge of the CFI by the High Court Ordinance (Cap. 4) in relation to civil cases.
A Family Judge hearing a family proceeding has all the powers conferred on a judge of the District Court by the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336) in relation to civil cases.

section.name: s14
section.heading: Power of judge in chambers
section.content: A judge may exercise in chambers the jurisdiction vested in the court in relation to family proceedings as provided by the Rules.

section.name: s15
section.heading: Jurisdiction, powers and duties of Registrar and Master

subsection.content: The Registrar may under the general or special directions of a judge hear and determine an application or matter in a family proceeding that may be heard and determined in chambers.
All the jurisdiction, powers and duties conferred on the Registrar in relation to family proceedings may be exercised and performed by a Master.

part.name: P3
part.heading: Practice and Procedure

section.name: s16
section.heading: Proceedings generally started in Family Court
section.leadIn: Subject to section 17, a family proceeding for a matter must start in the Family Court unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the CFI has exclusive jurisdiction in the matter;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: another enactment requires the proceeding to start in the CFI; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: there are exceptional circumstances.

section.name: s17
section.heading: Proceedings in original court for specific applications
section.leadIn: An application in relation to an order or direction referred to in the following provisions must be made to the court that made the order or direction—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: section 7(1) or 9C(10) of the Separation and Maintenance Orders Ordinance (Cap. 16);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: section 48(2) or (3), 48A(5) or 53B(10) of the Matrimonial Causes Ordinance (Cap. 179);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: section 5(6) of the Maintenance Orders (Reciprocal Enforcement) Ordinance (Cap. 188);

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: section 7A of the Domestic and Cohabitation Relationships Violence Ordinance (Cap. 189);

paragraph.name: f
g
paragraph.content: section 13(1) of the Parent and Child Ordinance (Cap. 429) (in so far as it relates to the revocation or variation of a direction);

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: section 8(1), 9(2) or 18(1) of the Inheritance (Provision for Family and Dependants) Ordinance (Cap. 481).

section.name: s18
section.heading: Proceedings generally heard in private

subsection.content: Unless otherwise provided by an enactment, a family proceeding, whether held in court or in chambers, must be heard in private and in accordance with the Practice Direction on mode of hearing.
However, subject to subsection (3), a matrimonial cause must be heard in open court.
In a proceeding for nullity of marriage, evidence on the question of sexual capacity must be heard in private.

Despite subsection (1), the court may, having regard to Article 10 of the Hong Kong Bill of Rights set out in Part II of the Hong Kong Bill of Rights Ordinance (Cap. 383), order the hearing of a family proceeding to be open to the public.

Despite subsection (2), the court may, having regard to Article 10 of the Hong Kong Bill of Rights set out in Part II of the Hong Kong Bill of Rights Ordinance (Cap. 383), order the hearing of a matrimonial cause to be in private.

section.name: s19
section.heading: Appeals from CFI

subsection.content: Unless otherwise provided by an enactment, an appeal lies as of right to the Court of Appeal from an order of the CFI in a family proceeding.

subsection.leadIn: No appeal lies to the Court of Appeal from the following orders or decision—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an order of the CFI allowing an extension of time for appealing from an order;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an order of the CFI that is provided by an enactment to be final;

paragraph.name: c
d
e
paragraph.content: a decision of the CFI in respect of which a certificate is granted under section 27C of the Hong Kong Court of Final Appeal Ordinance (Cap. 484) and leave to appeal is granted under section 27D of that Ordinance in a family proceeding.

subsection.content: Unless otherwise provided by the Rules, no appeal lies to the Court of Appeal from an interlocutory order of the CFI in a family proceeding unless permission to appeal has been given by the CFI or the Court of Appeal.

subsection.leadIn: Permission to appeal may be given—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in respect of a particular issue arising out of the interlocutory order; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to the conditions considered by the court hearing the application to be necessary in order to secure the just, expeditious and economical disposal of the appeal.

subsection.leadIn: Permission to appeal must not be given unless the court hearing the application is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the appeal has a reasonable prospect of success; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: there is some other reason in the interests of justice for the appeal to be heard.

section.name: s20
section.heading: Appeals from Family Court

subsection.content: Unless otherwise provided by an enactment, no appeal lies to the Court of Appeal from an order of a Family Judge in a family proceeding unless permission to appeal has been given by a Family Judge or the Court of Appeal.

No appeal lies to the Court of Appeal from an order absolute for the dissolution or nullity of marriage where a party who, having had time and opportunity to appeal from the decree nisi on which the order was founded, has not appealed from that decree.
An appeal lies as of right to a Family Judge in chambers from an order of a Master in a family proceeding.
An appeal also lies as of right to the Court of Appeal by a person against whom an order is made under section 20, 48B, 52D, 52E or 53(3) of the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336).

subsection.leadIn: Permission to appeal may be given—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in respect of a particular issue arising out of the order referred to in subsection (1); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to the conditions considered by the Family Judge or the Court of Appeal hearing the application to be necessary in order to secure the just, expeditious and economical disposal of the appeal.

subsection.leadIn: Permission to appeal must not be given unless the Family Judge or the Court of Appeal hearing the application is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the appeal has a reasonable prospect of success; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: there is some other reason in the interests of justice for the appeal to be heard.

section.name: s21
section.heading: Application of High Court rules and practice
section.content: To the extent that no provision is made by this Ordinance or the Rules for the practice or procedure applicable to a family proceeding in the High Court or the Family Court, the Rules of the High Court (Cap. 4 sub. leg. A) and the practice of the High Court apply unless the court conducting the proceeding otherwise directs.

section.name: s22
section.heading: Practice Directions

subsection.content: The Chief Justice may make directions as to the practice and procedure of the court on one or more types of family proceedings.
The Chief Justice may designate a High Court Judge to make any of the directions referred to in subsection (1).

section.name: s23
section.heading: Rules Committee to specify forms

subsection.content: The Rules Committee may specify one or more forms to be used for a matter provided for in this Ordinance or for the purposes of any provision of this Ordinance.
A form specified under this section must be completed in accordance with the instructions and directions that are specified in the form.

part.name: P4
part.heading: Family Procedure Rules Committee

section.name: s24
section.heading: Establishment of Family Procedure Rules Committee

subsection.content: The Family Procedure Rules Committee is established.

subsection.leadIn: The Rules Committee consists of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Chief Judge, who is the Chairperson;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a High Court Judge nominated by the Chief Judge;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the Registrar of the High Court, or a Master of the High Court nominated by the Chief Judge to represent the Registrar;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the Principal Family Court Judge;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: a Family Judge nominated by the Chief Judge;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the Registrar of the District Court, or a Master of the District Court nominated by the Chief Judge to represent the Registrar;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: 2 barristers nominated by the Hong Kong Bar Association;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: 2 solicitors nominated by The Law Society of Hong Kong; and
the Secretary for Justice, or a legal officer in the Department of Justice nominated by the Secretary.

subsection.content: At a meeting of the Rules Committee, 5 members form a quorum of whom one must be a member specified in subsection (2)(g) or (h).
The member specified in subsection (2)(c) is the secretary of the Rules Committee.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: barrister (大律師) has the meaning given by section 2(1) of the Legal Practitioners Ordinance (Cap. 159);
legal officer in the Department of Justice (律政司律政人員) means a person holding one of the offices in the Department of Justice mentioned in Schedule 1 to the Legal Officers Ordinance (Cap. 87);
solicitor (律師) has the meaning given by section 2(1) of the Legal Practitioners Ordinance (Cap. 159).

section.name: s25
section.heading: Rule-making powers of Rules Committee

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: make rules for regulating and prescribing the practice and procedure for family proceedings in the High Court and the Family Court;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in relation to any matter relating to a family proceeding, make rules for better carrying out the purposes of—

subparagraph.content: the High Court Ordinance (Cap. 4), in particular sections 14, 14AA, 21M, 26, 41, 42, 44, 52A and 52B of that Ordinance;
the Guardianship of Minors Ordinance (Cap. 13), in particular section 20 of that Ordinance;
the Separation and Maintenance Orders Ordinance (Cap. 16), in particular section 9A of that Ordinance;
section 9(3) of the Marriage Reform Ordinance (Cap. 178);
the Matrimonial Causes Ordinance (Cap. 179), in particular sections 11A, 14 and 49 of that Ordinance;
the Marriage Ordinance (Cap. 181), in particular section 18A of that Ordinance;
the Married Persons Status Ordinance (Cap. 182);
the Legitimacy Ordinance (Cap. 184);
the Maintenance Orders (Reciprocal Enforcement) Ordinance (Cap. 188);
the Domestic and Cohabitation Relationships Violence Ordinance (Cap. 189);
the Matrimonial Proceedings and Property Ordinance (Cap. 192), in particular sections 12, 25 and 28 of that Ordinance;
the Adoption Ordinance (Cap. 290), in particular section 5A of that Ordinance;
the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336), in particular sections 47A, 47D, 52B, 53 and 53A of that Ordinance;
the Parent and Child Ordinance (Cap. 429), in particular sections 6 and 12 of that Ordinance;
the Inheritance (Provision for Family and Dependants) Ordinance (Cap. 481);
the Child Abduction and Custody Ordinance (Cap. 512); and
the Mainland Judgments in Matrimonial and Family Cases (Reciprocal Recognition and Enforcement) Ordinance (Cap. 639); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: without limiting paragraphs (a) and (b), make rules for the purposes set out in section 26.

section.name: s26
section.heading: Rules for general matters

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting section 25, rules may be made under that section for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: regulating case management;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: regulating matters relating to alternative dispute resolution;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: regulating proceedings involving a deceased person or the estate of a deceased person;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: empowering the Registrar to deal with any matter relating to—

subparagraph.content: costs to be taxed under a costs order; and
interests on taxed costs or costs of taxation;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: prescribing the procedure in connection with the transfer and retransfer of family proceedings between the CFI and the Family Court;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: prescribing the practice and procedure for an application for a financial order in family proceedings;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: regulating matters relating to appeals against orders of the court in family proceedings;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: prescribing the jurisdiction of the court that may be exercised by the Registrar or a Master in family proceedings (including provision for appeals against orders made in the exercise of that jurisdiction);
prescribing fees and regulating matters relating to the fees and costs of family proceedings in the court;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: prescribing when persons absent, but having an interest in a family proceeding, must be bound by an order made in the proceeding;

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.leadIn: providing for the enforcement of orders made in family proceedings, including—

subparagraph.content: the prohibition of judgment debtors and persons against whom claims are made from leaving Hong Kong and ordering the payment of compensation to them in prescribed circumstances;
ordering the appearance of judgment debtors for examination; and
the arrest and imprisonment of judgment debtors;

paragraph.content: providing for matters relating to the variation, discharge, suspension, rescission, setting aside or revival of an order made in a family proceeding;

paragraph.name: m
paragraph.content: providing for the means by which particular facts may be proved in a family proceeding and the mode in which evidence of those facts may be given;

paragraph.name: n
paragraph.content: regulating matters relating to the giving of expert evidence and the submission of expert reports;

paragraph.name: o
paragraph.content: empowering the court to dispense with or relax any procedure, or shorten any time limit, specified in the Rules;
